medical_history.chief_complaint: L-dopa responsive dystonia (DRD) caused by tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Patient 1 exhibited normal psychomotor development until age 3, when he developed increasing walking difficulties, falls, augmented muscle tone, and dystonic posturing, leading to wheelchair dependence within 10 years. Patient 2 had delayed psychomotor development, possibly due to rhesus incompatibility, and also developed walking problems and dystonia after age 3, becoming wheelchair-bound within 7 years. The symptoms were effectively managed with L-dopa therapy initiated at ages 12 and 24, respectively, with significant improvement noted.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Both siblings were diagnosed with L-dopa responsive dystonia associated with a compound heterozygous mutation in the tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) gene.
medical_history.family_history: The mother was heterozygous for one of the mutations in the TH gene; no other relevant family history mentioned.
